title: What's the point of releasing champs like Zoe ?
body: They're an instant problem in solo and pro play. 70% ban rate, so even if you like the champ, you won't be able to play her. Constant problem for upcoming patches, have to nerf her every time... then once it's over, she's unplayable. Like what is the point of having play tester and whatnot if champs like her can go through ?

replies.body:
Because there's a department at Riot HQ that gets paid to make new champions, and clearly they have a rough quota to meet per quarter.

TBH, I'd rather Riot just stop making new champions and focus on their reworks of older champions and continue balancing the game around what's already here rather than keep introducing new champions. Or at least slow down the rate of new champions. Like...how many champions do you need in the game lol.
I really doubt League would collapse on itself if Riot stopped making champions...considering they make all their money from skins anyway.

Outside of Mr "I main this champ" the week they come out, how does reworking old champs not do all of the same stuff? They usually do skins with the reworks. Unless my I am not thinking of everyone last year 5 new champs came out, and only 3 reworks happened. Even if champs need a "minor" rework (like warwick) or a Major one like Galio and a few others, I don't see how they can get the game to a somewhat reasonable balance by adding in new champs so often. 

Every single new champ has shaken the game up tremendously, whether its a lane or a whole meta they throw large wrenches in an already difficult to balance game. I get that riot needs to make money and all, but every single year pro play cycles through the same crap over and over, which means the meta cycles through the same crap over and over. After two seasons generally people have seen it all more then once.  I don't see outside of gamer whales how riot plans to make tons of money off of a game that their biggest selling point is "Shiny new stuff" instead of fixing glaring problems like champs that, even if they are good, are extremely out dated like Fiddlesticks and Volibear.

A lot of times when you look at new releases they take core identities of previous champions, but just add to them.

Diana to Ekko
Irelia to Cammille
Nocturne to Rengar
And from what I can Tell Vayne to Kai'Sa

That is where my biggest issue is at least for the overall. They could have just updated many of the kits basically instead of making updated versions. I do fully get that they need a number of champs in the game and want to be creative, but honestly do they need to make as many new champs as they do?

> Also, champions suitable for reworks are still many but nevertheless a limited resource, there will come a time where no single champion is considered to be strongly outdated.

That is very true, which honestly could be less then a year out if they used the new champion development group to update. There might only be 10 or so champs I can think of and some like Yi, Irelia (they are already doing), and a few other of the pure stat check check champs they could do adjustments and/or champs like Sivir who is not really bad just sadly outdated. Then add more to the game.

Someone is forgetting all the bullshit {{champion:76}} caused years ago; skillshots don't automatically get a free pass for ridiculous damage just because they aren't point-and-click.  {{champion:142}} was on a level as if{{champion:76}}'s traps snared the target, stunned for ~1 second, then applied bonus true damage on a spear, all with about 300 more range.

Recently, i got filled as ADC vs a {{champion:101}} Support and a {{champion:15}} . Guess who won? Me. I took {{champion:222}} , built Grasp of the Undying, Second Wind, Bone plating and secondary Precision with Triumph and Legend: Bloodlines.

Switcharoo is an amazing Grasp tool, and Jinx generally attacks minions to set up her attack speed, so Grasp is a match made in heaven. Every time Xerath tried to nuke me, I'd take it, auto him back, proc grasp and heal myself and Second wind does the rest along with my Doran's Shield and Life steal. Then I built {{item:3156}} and mowed them both down. Then I proceeded into the normal Jinx kit.

You do what it takes to win. You don't build cookie cutter every game, because the other team is expecting cookie cutter. Why do you think the support chose Xerath? He wanted to be a lane bully that couldn't be killed. And he would. If I was a cookie cutter player.

P.S. Trash tier? I'm Plat II and Plat I. The Plat I is in provisionals.

Counterbuilding is not counterplay. What you need to realize is when people talk about a champion being unhealthy or broken, they are not saying that the champion is unbeatable in every situation, I agree with you that building magic resist is very effective against Zoe, but that doesn't mean that her kit is healthy, resistances are effective against every champion in the game, that doesn't mean that every champion in the game has a fair kit. In reality.... none of these champs has direct and constant counterplay. Their counterplay exists in itemization, or very specific niche counters, which usually don't exist on the team opposing them if they are chosen. Many of them absolutely just outrange and out spam whatever is thrown at them linearly. The only counterplay is realistically...... very risky ganks....and active teamwork. Almost none of them can be dueled 1v1, especially in a lane situation.

Most of these will win outright in ANY 1v1, and {{champion:44}} 's ult is usually extremely unfair when used, because you generally can't erase his teammates before the invuln procs, you're usually stunned, and you're already locked in combat so there's often no option to just "wait it out."

Grasp heals based off max HP. That's true. But an adc can proc it more than melees can, and it gives access to Second Wind, Bone Plating, and Overgrowth. It also adds reliable damage, and ADC consistently has the second highest HP scaling per level of any role in the game. It's about combating DOT damage, not about the grasp. Grasp just makes up some of the heals you lose from fleet footwork, procs more actively, and allows you to counter specific supports who are painful, like {{champion:143}} {{champion:63}} {{champion:101}} {{champion:161}} , because Second wind will heal you out of a lot of the damage they put on you in addition to Grasp. 

Coup degras has been nerfed, and you can still pick 2 precisions as a Grasp adc, so in reality you can still grab Triumph and a Legend rune with Grasp, and have a hell of a heal capability (I generally have Triumph and Legend: Bloodlines on a Grasp build)

Fleet is not going to sustain you in a lane vs DoT damage.

Grasp heals for 2 % of max HP per 4 seconds. Jinx can spam it. Dunno where you get the idea competent players can dodge a 620-700 range basic attack vs another competent player. And again. It's NOT about Grasp. It's about Grasp + Second wind + Overgrowth. You will outheal any DOT damage. I don't use Grasp EVERY GAME. But when I do, I end games with some 18,000 heals, and outlane the FF champs, because they are lower range and can't hit me.

It finished in Silver. It started in Gold V and climbed to Gold IV. Only ~ 16 days after the account was made. Then I went 13% win rate with Evelynn for the first 10 days of her remake, experimenting with builds, because her kit wasn't made for the old rune systems (she couldn't even Baron because the old jungle items didn't heal enough, and Ravenous Hunter didn't exist; Baron 3 shot her). By the end of the season (a whopping 44 days after that account was made), I had Evelynn to 44% from that 13%, and I'm running 72% win rate now.
